DFT calculations were conducted to explore the mechanisms and origins of feeding sequence-controlled divergent selective hydrosilylation of terminal alkyne catalyzed by rhodium complex. The calculation results reveal that varying feeding sequences of reactants (silane and alkyne) lead to the formation of distinct active catalysts, each following a different reaction mechanism. Under a stepwise feeding strategy, the reaction follows a Haszeldine-like mechanism, yielding the anti-Markovnikov anti-addition product, β-(Z)-vinylsilane (3a). In contrast, the one-step feeding process proceeds via the Chalk–Harrod mechanism, producing the anti-Markovnikov syn-addition product, β-(E)-vinylsilane (4a). The observed anti-Markovnikov regioselectivity in both strategies primarily stems from little steric hindrance and the spherical nature of the hydrogen 1s orbital. The E/Z stereoselectivity is governed by different active catalysts generated through distinct feeding sequences, which in turn govern the reaction pathways and stereoselective outcomes. These mechanistic insights offer a deeper understanding of the title reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords DFT Hydrosilylation Regioselectivity Stereoselectivity Terminal alkyne Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Alkyne functionalization stands as a highly dynamic field within modern synthetic chemistry, enabling the direct synthesis of a wide range of functionalized alkenes. Vinylsilanes, widely employed as versatile reagents and intermediates in the production of various silicon-containing materials and fine chemicals, are favored for numerous advantageous properties, such as low cost, low toxicity and ease of handling [1–3]. Consequently, the efficient synthesis of vinylsilanes has become a central focus in synthetic chemistry. Among the various synthetic approaches, transition metal-catalyzed hydrosilylation of alkynes (such as Ru [4–14], Rh [15–27], Ir [28–31], Pt [32–34], etc. [35–38]) stands out as the most direct and widely employed method. However, despite its popularity, achieving precise control over regio- and stereoselectivity remains a significant challenge. Typically, the hydrosilylation of terminal alkynes can yield three isomers – the Markovnikov α-vinylsilane, the anti-Markovnikov β-(Z)-vinylsilane via anti-addition, and the β-(E)-vinylsilane via syn-addition (Scheme 1 a). Achieving highly selective hydrosilylation requires careful optimization of various factors, including catalyst, substrate, ligand, and others [39,40]. Excitingly, the Mori group successfully controlled the regio- and stereoselectivity of rhodium-catalyzed hydrosilylation by simply adjusting the feeding sequences of two reactants, silane and alkyne (Scheme 1b) [21–23]. When both reactants, terminal alkyne 1a and silane 2a, were introduced simultaneously (one-step feeding), the reaction yielded the highly selective syn-addition product 4a. In contrast, when silane 2a was first allowed to react with catalyst for two hours before the addition of alkyne 1a (stepwise feeding), the anti-addition product 3a was predominantly formed. Notably, Mori et al. found that the reaction temperatures (60 °C vs. room temperature) had little influence on reaction selectivity. Even at 60 °C, the stepwise feeding approach still favored 3a as the major product. The intriguing feeding sequence control strategy aroused our interest in uncovering the underlying mechanisms and origins of the observed selectivity, inspiring further mechanistic investigations. Numerous mechanisms for the hydrosilylation of alkenes and alkynes have been extensively investigated [41–44]. Traditionally, hydrosilylation follows either the CH or mCH mechanism (Scheme 2 a), both of which initiate with the oxidative addition of the Si-H bond to the catalyst. In the CH mechanism [39,40], the alkyne undergoes migratory insertion into the M–H bond, followed by reductive elimination, yielding the syn-addition product β-(E). In contrast, the mCH mechanism [43] involves initial insertion of the alkyne into the M-Si bond, followed by isomerization via metallacyclopropene or zwitterionic intermediates and subsequent reductive elimination, affording the anti-addition product β-(Z). To account for β-(Z) product formation, Haszeldine proposed an alternative mechanism [44] (Scheme 2b) involving two silane molecules. In this pathway, the first silane undergoes the CH mechanism, producing a metal-coordinated β-(E)-vinylsilane intermediate. The second silane then inserts into the metal-carbon bond, forming a metal−alkyl silicide. Subsequent carbon-carbon bond rotation and β-elimination yield the β-(Z)-vinylsilane. However, the underlying reaction mechanism of this feeding sequence-controlled hydrosilylation remains elusive. Building upon previously proposed mechanisms, extensive computational studies have been conducted to elucidate the underlying principles of hydrosilylation [6,9,10,12,31,45–49]. For instance, Wu et al. investigated a series of Ru-catalyzed hydrosilylation reactions and identified the novel Wu-Trost mechanism [7,9,10,12], which provided crucial insights into the mechanistic pathway and origin of high selectivity in hydrosilylation. In 2021, our group explored the ligand-tuned, manganese-catalyzed divergent silylation of alkenes, revealing the pivotal role of ligand effects in modulating hydrosilylation pathways [46]. However, the mechanistic basis of feeding sequence-controlled, highly selective hydrosilylation remains poorly understood, and the key factors governing selectivity have yet to be fully clarified. To address this gap, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate reaction mechanism, aiming to uncover the origin of the feeding sequence-controlled selectivity. 2 Computational details All the calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 packages [50] under experimental solution condition (solvent = toluene) with SMD solvent model [51,52]. The geometry optimizations were carried out without any constraints using B3LYP-D3 method [53–56] of DFT. The 6–31G(d) basis set [57–59] was used for all the atoms except for Rh and I atoms, which were described by the LANL2DZ [60–62] basis set with effective core potential (denoted as BS1). Frequency analysis at the same level of theory was also conducted to identify the optimized structures as intermediate (zero imaginary frequency) or transition state (one imaginary frequency). The intrinsic reaction coordinate analysis [63,64] was carried out to ensure that all the transition states points were smoothly connected to each other. Single-point energies were conducted in solution phase by using the B3LYP-D3 method in conjugation with a larger basis set 6–311G(d, p) [65,66] for main groups and SDD [67–69] for Rh and I atoms (denoted as BS2). The reported free energies were solution-phase single-point energies corrected by solution-phase free energy corrections (see Eq. (1)). (1) G ( sol ) B 3 LYP = E ( sol ) B 3 LYP + G ( sol ) correction where E(sol)B3LYP is the solution-phase single-point energy calculated at the B3LYP-D3/BS2 level and G(sol)correction is the thermochemical correction calculated for Gibbs free energies in solution-phase at the B3LYP-D3/BS1 level. All reported free energies in this text corresponded to the reference state of 1 mol/L and 298.15 K [70–72]. Natural bond orbital (NBO) [73] population analysis was carried out by using the NBO version 3.1 implemented in Gaussian 09 program. Gibbs free energy correction at 60 °C (333.15 K) was calculated using Shermo software [74], which has been widely applied for evaluating temperature-dependent effects on reaction mechanisms [75,76]. The 3D structures were visualized by the CYLview [77] software. Different DFT functionals and basis sets were tested to validate the suitability of the selected calculation method (Tables S2 and S3). Results demonstrate the selected method is suitable for the present system. Detailed discussions are presented in the Supporting Information. We also investigated the effect of reaction temperature (25 °C and 60 °C) on the energy barriers of the stereoselective-determining steps (Fig. S1). The results show that although the temperature variation influenced the magnitude of the energy barriers, it did not alter the overall reaction selectivity. 3 Results and discussion The representative system shown in Scheme 1b is chosen as the model reaction to explore the hydrosilylation mechanism of terminal alkyne (1a) under the catalysis of rhodium complexes RhI(PPh3)3 (cat). First, we investigate the possible mechanisms for the formation of β-(Z)-vinylsilane product (3a) in a stepwise feeding strategy. Then, the mechanism in the one-step feeding method to form the β-(E)-vinylsilane (4a) is investigated. Finally, the origins of feeding sequence-controlled selectivity are rationalized. 3.1 Hydrosilylation mechanisms via a stepwise feeding strategy 3.1.1 Formation of the active catalyst IM3 When the reactant silane 2a is first introduced into the reactor and allowed to react with catalyst RhI(PPh3)3 for 2 h, it undergoes oxidative addition, generating the active catalyst IM3. Fig. 1 illustrates the free energy profiles of the oxidative addition process and the key structures involved. There are three possible pathways. Silane 2a may either replace the I anion (paths 1 and 2), or the PPh3 group at a cis (path 3) or trans (path 4) position to the I anion, followed by the oxidative addition of Si–H bond to the Rh(I) center. As depicted in Fig. 1, although the oxidative addition barrier in path 3 (6.8 kcal/mol) is lower than those in path 1 (17.7 kcal/mol), path 2 (19.9 kcal/mol) and path 4 (20.8 kcal/mol), the addition intermediate IM3 is thermodynamically more stable than IM3b by 10.1 kcal/mol. Furthermore, the reverse process (IM3b→cat) is facile, requiring overcoming a barrier of 8.1 kcal/mol. Therefore, the addition of only silane and catalyst to the reaction results in the formation of the final stable intermediate IM3. IM3 and IM3b both adopt a square-pyramidal configuration. The relative stability of IM3 to IM3b can be explained by the trans-influence order of the ligands: SiMe2(OSiMe3)– > H – > PPh3 > I – [79]. In IM3, the H takes the position trans to I anion, whereas in IM3b, the H is located at the trans position to the PPh3 ligand. Consequently, IM3 is relatively more stable due to the combination of a strong and weak trans-influence, which stabilizes the complex more effectively than a combination of a strong and strong trans-influence in IM3b. Additionally, we investigate other isomers of IM3 with different ligands at the apical of the square-pyramid configuration and varying orientations of the [Si] group. Calculation results (Fig. S2) show that IM3 is much more stable than other isomers. This can be attributed to the strong trans-effect of the silicon group, which makes its trans-position less favorable for coordination. Previous experimental and theoretical studies further support this conclusion. The Osakada group obtained the X-ray crystal structure of IM3 during their investigation of the oxidative addition of hydrosilane to RhI(PPh3)3 [78], providing direct evidence for the existence of IM3. Hasegawa’s theoretical study found that the configuration of the analogous chlorine-coordinated silylrhodium(III) complex [(Cl)HRh(SiMe3)(PMe3)3] is identical to IM3, with the [Si] group at the apical and other ligands at the base of the square pyramid, which is the most stable configuration [79,80]. In summary, in the stepwise feeding process, silane 2a reacts with the catalyst cat undergoing oxidative addition, ultimately forming active catalyst IM3. 3.1.2 Hydrosilylation mechanism of terminal alkyne 1a from active catalyst IM3 After the silane reacts with the catalyst for 2 h forming active catalyst IM3, alkyne 1a is introduced into the reactor, where it first coordinates to Rh center, substituting one ligand in IM3. Three possible coordination modes lead to the formation of different substitution intermediates: IM4, IM4–1 and IM4–2. The free energy barriers and energy profiles for the alkyne insertion process of these intermediates are depicted in Figs. 2 and S3. Among the isomers, IM4 is the most stable, being 2.0 and 4.4 kcal/mol more stable than IM4–1 and IM4–2, respectively. All three isomers are potential candidates for the subsequent alkyne insertion step. For IM4, two insertion pathways-into the Rh–H or Rh–Si bond, govern the regioselectivity. Alkyne insertion into the Rh–H bond (ΔG‡ TS2 = 17.5 kcal/mol) is kinetically more favorable than insertion into the Rh–Si bond (ΔG‡ TS2 α = 42.1 kcal/mol and ΔG‡ TS2 β = 31.1 kcal/mol). Similarly, IM4–1 and IM4–2 exhibit the same kinetic preference for Rh–H bond insertion. Among the three intermediates, IM4 exhibits the lowest barrier for 1,2-insertion into Rh–H bond (17.5 kcal/mol), compared to IM4–1 and IM4–2 (19.2 and 20.8 kcal/mol, respectively). Direct insertion of alkyne into Rh–H bond without pre-coordination is ruled out due to the high barrier (36.3 kcal/mol via TS2a in Fig. S3). Consequently, upon alkyne introduction, the vinyl Rh(III) intermediate IM5 is initially formed, undergoing the kinetically favorable 1,2-insertion into Rh–H bond. As shown in Fig. 3 , intermediate IM5 adopts a seesaw configuration with a vacant site, allowing reductive elimination to occur either directly or following pre-coordination. Elimination after ligand coordination (paths I-III) is kinetically and thermodynamically more favorable than direct elimination (path IV) (Figs. 3 and S4). Among these, elimination after alkyne 1a coordination (path I) has the lowest barrier, being 3.1 kcal/mol and 2.5 kcal/mol lower than elimination after silane 2a (path II) and PPh3 (path III) coordination, respectively. Consistent with the ruthenacyclopropene complex formed via rotation, as reported by Wu et al. [6,7,10], we also consider the rotation transition state across C=C double bond in IM5. However, the high energy barrier (31.4 kcal/mol via TS3–4) indicates that such a Rh metallacyclopropene is unlikely to exist. Following reductive elimination, a square-planar intermediate IM7 is formed, where the alkyne is replaced by silane 2a, forming intermediate IM8. This intermediate undergoes oxidative addition of the Si-H bond to the Rh center via TS4, resulting in the stable intermediate IM9. Four competing pathways from IM9 may proceed: alkene insertion into the Rh–H bond (path a) or the Rh-Si bond (path c), direct alkene dissociation (path b) [81], and alkene dissociation accompanied by the coordination of a PPh3 ligand (path d). As shown in Fig. 3, path a is both kinetically and thermodynamically more favorable than paths b, c and d. Consequently, IM9 undergoes alkene insertion into the Rh-H bond to form IM10, which preferentially rotates along the C α –C β single bond (ΔG‡ TS6 = 9.9 kcal/mol), rather than undergoing alkyl-silyl reductive elimination (ΔG‡ TS6– 1 = 39.3 kcal/mol) (Fig. 4 ). The resulting intermediate IM11, features the [Si] and phenyl groups on the same side. Unlike IM5, where rotation is disfavored due to the C α –C β double bond, the single bond in IM10 allows rotation to proceed more readily. In IM10 and IM11, as evidenced by the elongation of the C–H bond (C β –H1: 1.20 Å in IM10, C β –H2: 1.17 Å in IM11 in Fig. S5), favoring subsequent β-H elimination. Elimination via TS7 produces the product β-(Z)-vinylsilanes-coordinated intermediate IM12, which ultimately undergoes alkene dissociation and PPh3 coordination to regenerate the active catalyst IM3, liberating product 3a. In the stepwise feeding hydrosilylation, the alkyne 1,2-insertion into Rh-H bond has the highest barrier (17.5 kcal/mol via TS2) and thus is considered as the rate-determining step over the catalytic cycle. 3.2 Hydrosilylation mechanisms in one-step feeding of both reactants When both reactants are simultaneously introduced into the reaction, they may coordinate to the Rh center, replacing one or two PPh3 ligand on the catalyst. The free energy profiles for this hydrosilylation reaction are shown in Figs. 5 , S6 and S7. As shown in Fig. 5, the initial Si-H oxidative addition process from IM1b (path 3 of Fig. 1) is kinetically the most favorable pathway. Alternative pathways are ruled out due to higher free energy barriers (Fig. S6). Thus, under one-step feeding condition, the reaction preferentially proceeds via path 3 to form intermediate IM3b, instead of following path 1 to generate intermediate IM3, which is favored under stepwise feeding. This selectivity arises from the substantially lower barrier of path 3 compared to path 1, as well as the more favorable energy barrier of the subsequent alkyne insertion from intermediate IM3b, correctively rendering path 3 the kinetically preferred route. Subsequently, the alkyne can replace either of the two PPh3 ligands in IM3b coordinating to the Rh center and forming intermediates IM17, IM17–1 and IM17b, as illustrated in Figs. S6 and 5. Among these, IM17 undergoes a kinetically favorable 1,2-insertion of the alkyne into the Rh-H bond (ΔG‡ TS11 = 13.3 kcal/mol, TS11 relative to IM16), whereas insertion into Rh-Si bond is significantly less favorable (1,2-insertion: ΔG‡ TS11 α = 44.0 kcal/mol, 2,1-insertion: ΔG‡ TS11 β = 24.4 kcal/mol). Other potential insertion pathways for intermediate IM17–1 and IM17b are ruled out due to their higher activation barriers (Fig. S7). Following insertion, the resulting intermediate IM18 preferentially undergoes alkyl-silyl reductive elimination directly via TS12 rather than C–C bond rotation or pre-coordination (Fig. S8), leading to the formation of the product-coordinated intermediate IM19 (Fig. 5). IM19 adopts a square-planar geometry, in which the CC double bond and the oxygen atom of the vinylsilane coordinate to the Rh center. Subsequent substitution of PPh3 ligand via TS13 is kinetically favored over a second silane addition by 3.5 kcal/mol. Consequently, the phosphine ligand displaces the oxygen atom coordinated to the Rh center, forming intermediate IM22, which undergoes the alkene dissociation via TS14 to liberate product 4a and regenerate the catalyst. To further investigate whether silanes lacking the ether moiety can still undergo the CH mechanism, we conducted additional calculations on HSiEt3 (2b), an experimentally employed silane [21]. The results show that, in contrast to silyl ether 2a, silane 2b coordinates to the Rh center solely through CC double bond in intermediate IM19–2b (Fig. S9), and cannot form a dual-coordinated intermediate like IM19. However, computational analysis of the stereoselective-determining steps (Table S4) reveals that this substrate still preferentially proceeds via the CH mechanism. These findings suggest that while dual coordination, as observed in IM19 with 2a may enhance intermediate stability, it is not essential for the CH mechanism to occur. 3.3 Origins of different selectivity between two feeding strategies 3.3.1 Origins of anti-Markovnikov regioselectivity Based on the above calculation results, it is evident that, whether using a stepwise or one-step feeding protocol, the formation of anti-Markovnikov β-vinylsilane is always more favorable than that of Markovnikov α-vinylsilane. This aligns qualitatively with the experimental findings [21–23]. The insertion pattern of alkyne determines the regioselectivity of the hydrosilylation reaction. It is observed that insertion into Rh-H bond is preferred over insertion into Rh-Si bond in both feeding strategies. As shown in Fig. 6 , the energy barrier for the 1,2-insertion of the alkyne into Rh-Si bond, is much higher than that for 2,1-insertion, leading to the anti-Markovnikov product (stepwise feeding: 42.1 kcal/mol versus 31.1 kcal/mol in TS2α and TS2β , respectively; one-step feeding: 44.0 kcal/mol versus 24.4 kcal/mol in TS11α and TS11β , respectively). This is understandable since TS2α and TS11α experience severe steric crowding between the silyl group and phenyl group, whereas such steric hindrance is little in TS2β and TS11β . Additionally, electron effects further favor 2,1-insertion over 1,2-insertion into Rh-Si bond. The C β atom carries a more negative charge than the C α atom (−0.201e versus 0.016e and −0.211e versus 0.042e for C β and C α atom in IM4 and IM17, respectively). As a result, the positively charged silyl groups more readily migrate to the negatively charged C β atom than to the positively charged C α atom. Nevertheless, the 1,2-insertion of the alkyne into the Rh-H bond is kinetically much more favorable than the 2,1-insertion into the Rh-Si bond (stepwise feeding: 17.5 kcal/mol in TS2 versus 31.1 kcal/mol in TS2β ; one-step feeding: 13.3 kcal/mol in TS11 versus 24.4 kcal/mol in TS11β ). This finding aligns well with the experimentally observed regioselectivity. The kinetic preference for insertion into the Rh-H bond over the Rh-Si bond can be attributed to the greater orbital overlap of the less directional Rh-H bond, stemming from the spherical nature of the hydrogen 1s orbital. In contrast, the more directional Rh-Si bond exhibits reduced overlap. Furthermore, the formation of a CH bond is associated with lower steric hindrance compared to that of a C-Si bond [82,83]. Additionally, the insertion in TS2 and TS11 occurs nearly within the Rh-C β -C α plane (Rh-C β -C α -H dihedral angles: 5.7° in TS2 and 5.3° in TS11), whereas the silyl group is out of this plane by 48.1° in TS2β and 42.8° in TS11β , further corroborating these findings. 3.3.2 Origins of E/Z stereoselectivity Scheme 3 depicts a schematic diagram summarizing the key distinct steps leading to the generation of distinct stereoselective products through different feeding sequences. The order of reactant addition plays a crucial role in dictating the reaction pathways. In the stepwise feeding process, only silane 2a is initially introduced, allowing it sufficient time to react with catalyst via path 1, forming the thermodynamically stable active intermediate IM3 rather than the unstable IM3b, as observed experimentally. In contrast, simultaneous addition of silane and alkyne (one-step feeding) leads to the formation of a stable alkyne-coordinated intermediate IM16, which then proceeds through path 3 to generate IM3b. This species undergoes favorable 1,2-insertion into Rh-H bond via TS11, rather than the reverse process (IM3b→cat→IM3) due to the lower energy barrier of the 1,2-insertion step (13.3 kcal/mol) compared to the reverse process (20.6 kcal/mol, TS1 relative to IM16). Consequently, in stepwise feeding, IM3 serves as the active catalyst, initiating the catalytic cycle via a Haszeldine-like mechanism to yield the anti-addition Z-vinylsilane 3a. In one-step feeding, however, the catalyst (cat) follows a Chalk-Harrod mechanism, producing the syn-addition E-vinylsilane 4a. These findings highlight that the feeding sequence determines the formation of distinct active catalysts, thereby governing divergent reaction pathways and controlling stereoselectivity. 4 Conclusions In summary, DFT calculations were carried out to elucidate the mechanism of rhodium-catalyzed hydrosilylation and the origins of divergent selectivity controlled by the feeding sequence. The calculated results show that conventional CH mechanism and its variant are not applicable to the stepwise feeding hydrosilylation. Instead, the reaction proceeds via a Haszeldine-like mechanism. It starts with the oxidative addition of the Si–H bond in silane to the catalyst, generating the stable active species IM3, which has been experimentally observed and initiates the catalytic cycle. This cycle involves sequential alkyne insertion into Rh–H bond followed by alkyl-silyl reductive elimination, forming the β-(E)-vinylsilane-coordinated intermediate IM7; Subsequently, another silane molecule coordinates to the vacant site on IM7, followed by the Si–H oxidative addition, olefin insertion into Rh–H bond, C–C bond rotation and β-H elimination, ultimately yielding the β-(Z)-vinylsilane product 3a. In contrast, the one-step feeding hydrosilylation follows a conventional CH mechanism, where no active catalytic species like IM3 is formed. Instead, the process involves Si–H oxidative addition, alkyne insertion into Rh–H bond, and alkyl-silyl reductive elimination, yielding the β-(E)-vinylsilane product 4a. The catalyst cat is then regenerated via ligand substitution and alkene dissociation. The regioselectivity is determined by the alkyne migratory insertion step, where the preference for 1,2-insertion into Rh–H bond is attributed to little steric hindrance and the spherical nature of the 1s orbital for hydrogen, favoring the formation of anti-Markovnikov products. The difference in E/Z-stereoselectivity between the two feeding strategies arises from the formation of distinct active catalytic species, leading to divergent reaction pathways. In the stepwise feeding, a stable square-pyramidal silylrhodium(III) intermediate IM3 is identified as the active catalyst, whereas in the one step feeding, an alkyne-coordinated rhodium intermediate IM15 is formed instead of IM3. These computational findings align with the experimentally observed regio- and stereoselectivity. coredata.dc:description: DFT calculations were conducted to explore the mechanisms and origins of feeding sequence-controlled divergent selective hydrosilylation of terminal alkyne catalyzed by rhodium complex. The calculation results reveal that varying feeding sequences of reactants (silane and alkyne) lead to the formation of distinct active catalysts, each following a different reaction mechanism. Under a stepwise feeding strategy, the reaction follows a Haszeldine-like mechanism, yielding the anti-Markovnikov anti-addition product, β-(Z)-vinylsilane (3a). In contrast, the one-step feeding process proceeds via the Chalk–Harrod mechanism, producing the anti-Markovnikov syn-addition product, β-(E)-vinylsilane (4a). The observed anti-Markovnikov regioselectivity in both strategies primarily stems from little steric hindrance and the spherical nature of the hydrogen 1s orbital. The E/Z stereoselectivity is governed by different active catalysts generated through distinct feeding sequences, which in turn govern the reaction pathways and stereoselective outcomes. These mechanistic insights offer a deeper understanding of the title reaction.
